article.title: Spin-1 two-impurity Kondo problem on a lattice

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 depicts a toy model of the strong-coupling limit in the Kondo problem. What does the model illustrate?
choices: The formation of a Kondo cloud around each impurity spin.
The competition between Kondo and RKKY interactions.
The effect of magnetic anisotropy on the impurity spin.
The concept of underscreening for a spin-1 impurity.
The basis states for a single spin S=1 in terms of two spins S=1/2.
The energy levels of a spin-1 impurity under the influence of anisotropy.
The effect of a magnetic field on the different spin configurations.
The spin-spin correlations between the impurity and a conduction electron.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key difference between the "Underscreened" and "Screened" states depicted in Figure 3?
choices: The total spin quantum number of the system.
The presence of magnetic anisotropy.
The formation of a singlet state between the dangling spin and an additional conduction electron.
The direction of the impurity spin.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4(b) primarily illustrate about the entanglement entropy between the impurity spin and the conduction spins?
choices: Finite J leads to full screening (S â†’ log 3), while J=0 leads to underscreening.
Increasing the Kondo coupling JK always leads to higher entanglement entropy.
The effect of magnetic anisotropy on the entanglement entropy is negligible.
The entanglement entropy saturates to a constant value in the strong coupling limit for both finite and zero J.

multiple_choice_question.text: The Hamiltonian in Formula (1) describes the two-impurity Kondo model. What does the term JK represent?
choices: The strength of the magnetic anisotropy.
The kinetic energy of the conduction electrons.
The Kondo coupling between the impurity spins and the conduction electrons.
The indirect exchange interaction between the two impurities.
